sender.senderstreetaddress: Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corp. Bldg 419, One Health Plaza

reaction.primarysourcereaction: haemolytic anaemia thought to be auto-immune in origin

summary.narrativeincludeclinical:
Initial solicited Clozaril registry report combining information received on 29 Jun 2007, 03 Jul 2007 and 04 Jul 2007 from a physician and pharmacist: This patient had been receiving Clozaril (clozapine) as treatment for schizophrenia since 29 May 2007. In 00 Jun 2007 ca. 2-3 weeks later the patient was hospitalized following a collapse where she was diagnosed with haemolytic anaemia thought to be auto-immune in origin. The patient's Hb was around 5 (no units) but following a blood transfusion this rose to 8.5. The patient was prescribed treatment with prednisolone, Augmentin, folic acid and Clexane. The patient also developed a high white blood cell count of 24.5x10^9/l. Clozaril treatment was discontinued due to anaemia. No reporter causality or patient outcome were provided. In the absence of information from a healthcare professional the sponsor's medical safety expert has provisionally assessed the elevated white blood cell count as suspected and the haemolytic anaemia as not suspected to be related to Clozaril therapy, based on available information.
Follow-up solicited Clozaril registry report received from a physician on 22 Nov 2007: This patient who had a history of obesity, sensitivity to haloperidol and irritable bowel syndrome, received treatment with Clozaril for complex PTSD (post traumatic stress disorder) and not schizophrenia as previously stated. On 03 Jul 2007, about 11 weeks after first starting treatment, Clozaril was withdrawn following development of pallor and autoimmune haemolytic anaemia. No antibodies were found on investigation of the anaemia. The patient showed substantial improvement following withdrawal of Clozaril. She also received treatment with omeprazole and co-trimoxazole for unknown indications. The haemoglobin decreased again to about 5.5 (no units) on 10 Aug 2007 but improved slightly with blood transfusion to 7.4 on 17 Aug 2007. On 17 Aug 2007 the patient developed abdominal pain, painful urination, shortness of breath and a pleural effusion. Her physical condition deteriorated and two days later, on 19 Aug 2007, she died following a cardiorespiratory arrest. A post mortem examination showed DVT (deep venous thrombosis) and pulmonary embolism. Causality with respect to Clozaril was reported as suspected for pallor, collapse and autoimmune haemolytic anaemia and possibly not suspected for abdominal pain, painful urination and shortness of breath. Causality was not reported for the events of pleural effusion, cardiorespiratory arrest, pulmonary embolism and deep venous thrombosis, however the Novartis Medical Safety Physician has provisionally assessed these events as suspected to be related to Clozaril, based on the available information.
Following an internal review done on 03 Dec 2012 it was observed that case PHFR2007GB02037 was duplicate of PHHY2009GB55164. So all information from case PHHY2009GB55164 was merged into the case PHFR2007GB02037 and case number PHHY2009GB55164 was deactivated: On 23 Jun 2007, the patient's haematocrift value was 17%, haemoglobin was 6.2 g/dl, red blood cell count was 1.84 x 10^9/L. On 27 Jul 2007, patient's mean cell haemoglobin was 37.8 pg, red blood cell count was 3.18 x 10^9/l. On 10 Aug 2007, the patient's haematocrift value was 21%, haemoglobin was 5.5 g/dl, mean cell haemoglobin was 41.1 pg, mean cell volume was 114 fl and red blood cell count was 1.33 x 10^9/l. On 17 Aug 2007, the patient's haematocrift value was 21 %, haemoglobin was 5.5 g/dl, mean cell haemoglobin was 38.8 pg, mean cell volume was 111 fl, red blood cell count was 1.91 x 10^9/l and reticulocyte was 190 x 10^9/L. The event blood transfusion was deleted and added as procedure. The seriousness of the event haemolytic anaemia thought to be auto-immune in origin and looked pale was life threatening.
summary.sendercomment:
Serious adverse event report; cardiorespiratory arrest, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism (death), assessed as unlisted according to the Core Data Sheet. It is Novartis' policy to assess a case with a fatal outcome as unlisted unless the label specifically mentions death as a possible outcome of the listed risks. In the absence of a reporting healthcare professional causality the sponsor's medical safety expert has provisionally assessed the event as suspected, based on currently available information.
Serious adverse event report, autoimmune haemolytic anaemia (involving inpatient hospitalisation), assessed as unlisted according to the Core Data Sheet due to greater severity. The following term (anaemia) is already included in the Core Data Sheet. Reporting healthcare professional causality is suspected.
Serious adverse event report, increased white blood cell count (involving inpatient hospitalisation), assessed as listed according to the Core Data Sheet. In the absence of a reporting healthcare professional causality the sponsor's medical safety expert has provisionally assessed the event as suspected, based on currently available information.
Occurrence of the events within 3 months of the onset of the study drug suggests there is a reasonable possibility of causal relationship for the events cardiorespiratory arrest, pulmonary embolism and DVT. The rest of the events are unassessable.
